deck: Ingrid Hillcraft works at the Harbinger Foundation. She is the resident psychologist, retro-cognitive/emotive telepath.
description: Ingrid is Peter Stanchek's first appointment in the Harbinger Foundation. She is a psychologist, retro-cognitive/emotive telepath, which gives her the ability to see into Peter's past and emotions. With the help of Darpan, she digs into Peter's mind to find the most traumatic points in his life. The memories he relived were when kids were teasing him and he used his powers that hurt another kid, when he tried to 'activate' his father's powers and put him into a coma and when his mom took him away to the hospital.

When using his powers, he is able to choke his victims by using small electrical charges to ozonate the air in their lungs. When he first meets Peter Stanchek, Peter is stressed out after a long day and thus very annoyed by Ion when he approaches. Ion's authoritative attitude sets Peter off and they go at it in a psionic fight. This fight marks Peter's first full-scale Psionic exchange.

deck: The Seven Enemies of Man have often been integrated into Shazam's long history.  It is Captain Marvel's duty to protect the world from these seven deadly sins.
description:
Origin

These demons caused chaos by controlling humans and affecting their basic sinful desires. The wizard Shazam took notice and captured these demons within seven stones. Their punishment was to remain within the Rock of Eternity encased in stone forever.

Story Arcs

Day of Vengeance (Infinite Crisis)

The Spectre was without a host and tricked into destroying the magical community. The Spectre fought and killed the wizard Shazam, and the Rock of Eternity was destroyed in the aftermath. Because of this it set the Seven Enemies of Man loose upon the world. Because of the Captain Marvel and the Marvel family must go into the world, rebuild the Rock of Eternity and capture the sins again. They succeed and Captain Marvel now takes over Shazam's place as caretaker of the Rock of Eternity. After taking the role upon himself he begins to hear the sins and his sanity begins to waver. He begins talking back to the sins, trying to control his new duty.

JLA: World Without a Justice League

The deadly sin Envy makes a bad situation worse. Green Arrow, Batman, Black Canary, and Manitou Dawn fight against The Key as he tries to destroy Gotham. The Key and Envy use their abilities together to get Green Arrow to fight against the Batman.

The New 52

After the Flashpoint, the Seven Enemies of Man were demonic entities that were once trapped within a skulled shaped box until the woman called Pandora accidently opened it. This allowed the Seven Deadly Sins to terrorise the planet and thus marked Pandora as one of the Trinity of Sin by the Circle of Eternity. At some point, the Sins were all imprisoned within human bodies until the modern age. During that time, the recently freed Black Adam sought out Sloth and returned him to his true nature. Afterwards, Black Adam freed the other remaining Sins and gained their loyalty as they feared his power to trap them once again. Thus, they worked with Black Adam to find the heir of the Wizard who prior to dying gave his magical power to a boy called Billy Batson. Whilst Black Adam searched for Batson, the Seven Enemies of Man took possession of a human host and became a giant fiery demon that attacked the city until Teth-Adam's defeat. This led to the Sins retreating into the world once more.

Whom Gods Would Destroy! / Primeval Scream! / The Race is in the Running / Beware Mr. Wrinkles! / The Devil and Captain Marvel

name: The Seven Enemies of Man

After a vietcong embush he manages to violently capture a woman fighter and starts raping her until Castle kills her. Shocked he goes to the river to clean himself up and then Frank Castle drowns him.

deck: The unnamed protagonist of Andy Riley's Bunny Suicide comic books. A cute little rabbit who, for unknown reasons, no longer wants to live.
description:
Origin

Bunny is famous for his hundreds of suicide attempts. Though he kills himself on every page of The Book Of Bunny Suicides, he is always alive on the next page. He is often accompanied by one or more other rabbits, with equally suicidal tendencies. Aside from obvious, slapstick style deaths, some of Bunny's suicide attempts stop a frame shy of showing the reader exactly how he kills himself, leaving the audience to imagine what happens next. Some of his suicide attempts also include pop culture references, for example Bunny's death at the hands of Darth Vader.

Bunny's suicides are also sometimes depicted after-the-fact. A good example of this is a strip which features a bee's nest in a tree, with dead Bunny lying at the foot of it next to a catapult. Such clever use of suggestion in the comic strip ensures that it is never gory, and rarely graphic, even though some of Bunny's deaths are horrendously violent.
name: A Bunny

deck: One member on Captain Castle's platoon. Grenade Specialist.
name: Tedrow

deck: Member of Captain Castle's platoon of Valley Forge base. He has some drug addiction problems. He comes from the gettho and has a bitter vision of America contrasting with Goodwin's one.
description:
Angel is a young soldier. He has angel wings drawn on his helmet.

When staying at Valley Forge, he cannot help but smoking heroine. He is one of Coltrane's customers. This worries Stevie Goodwin who doesn't hesistate to confront the drug fdealer about it. Apparently Angel smokes so he can forget the ghetto he comes from and where he is about to come back.

On one occasion he has a discussion with Stevie about "real America" and their views are quite different. He is not the idealistic young boy Goodwin is. He does not believe in the American dream, or in a good america. He is far bitter than that. He believes in an America that used to call him "nigger".

When Valley Forge is attacked by enemy, just before he dies, Angel tells Goodwin that God doesn't exist.
name: Angel

deck:
Colonel of the Valley Forge base. Completely discouraged and not willing to do anything more on the base. 
He pretends to be sick and lets Captain Castle welcome General Padden for his surprise inspection. 
He likes drinking.
description:
One more man destroyed by the Vietnam conflict. He is afraid to put things in order on Valley Forge because the last one who tried woke up next to a claymore. Quite depressed, he obviously doesn't care no more about the base, to the point that Captain Castle seriously thinks about throwing him a grenade while he is on the toilet.

He kills himself when Valley Forge is attacked by the enemy. One bullet in the head.
name: Colonel Ottman

deck: British secret agent and martial artist.
description:
Origin

Ebony Jones was an agent of the British Special Missions Squad.

Creation

Ebony was originally conceived to appear in a prospective new girls' comic intended to break away from the traditional mold of angst-ridden teen characters in favour of all action heroines. When the decision was taken not to go forward with the title, editor Bill Graham felt that Ebony was too good a concept to waste, and so transferred her to boys' comic The Crunch, where she debuted in issue 39, October 13th 1979, thus earning her a place in British comics history as the first Black female lead character in a British comic.

Character Development

A top British agent, Ebony worked with fellow agent Bleak. When Nazi war criminals took him prisoner in Merando, Italy, it was up to Ebony to rescue him.

issue_credits.name: Three of the Great Comic Heroes of Our Time!
Revolt on the Planet of Evil!
Mark Sabor... Gladiator of the Future!

name: Ebony

deck: The first Taxi Taylor. He was a mechanical genius whom build his own Wonder Car.
description:
Origin

The first Taxi Taylor

The first Taxi Taylor was a man and a mechanical genius. His Wonder Car had collapsible wings, allowing it to fly; travel underwater like a submarine, send and receive radio messages, use magnetic rays to move objects around, and is armed with powerful water jets to fight fires. It is heavily a rmoured, covered in six inch steel plates. It comes equipped with a belt which the driver can wear when he leaves the vehicle, with a programmable timer set to retrieve the wearer and return him to the safety of the car.

Whether this Taxi Taylor has a connection to the second female Taxi Taylor of ARMOR remains to be seen.

Creation

Taxi Taylor first appeared in Mystic Comics Issue 2.
name: Taxi Taylor

deck: A demon, and proprietor of Sir Sigmoid's Arcadia.
description:
Origin

Sir Sigmoid is a demon who runs a carnival in the Ectosphere, called Sir Sigmoid's Arcadia. He lulls children into the carnival, distracting them with games and attractions so he can feast on their souls. His sidekick is a tiny worm in a top hat named Tequila, who can jump into people's ears and take control of their minds.

Creation

Sir Sigmoid was created by Clive Barker.

Major Story Arcs

Sir Sigmoid appears in the story arc "Sir Sigmoid's Arcadia", a crossover between two Razorline titles: Ectokid and Saint Sinner.
name: Sir Sigmoid

deck: The Noid was a 1980s character seen in advertising for Domino's Pizza. He was a physical manifestation of the difficulties involved in delivering a pizza in 30 minutes or less.
description: He wore a red, skin-tight, rabbit-eared body suit with a black N inscribed in a white circle. His weapon was the "Pizza Crusher" a pogo-stick type weapon.
name: Noid

deck: A tiny worm who resides in the Ectosphere.
description:
Origin

Tequila is a small, evil worm who can take control of people's minds by jumping into their ears. His master is a demon named Sir Sigmoid.

Creation

Tequila was created by Clive Barker.

Major Story Arcs

Sir Sigmoid's Arcadia

Tequila's role at the Arcadia is to lure children inside. He can also use his powers of mind control to convince people to stay at the Arcadia. In Saint Sinner #5, he takes control of a young girl at the carnival, using her to keep Saint Sinner within the Ectosphere.
name: Tequila

deck: Danger Mouse's ever eager, often terrified, sidekick.
description:
Origin

Hamster Ernest Penfold is the assistant of top secret agent Danger Mouse. His own codename is the Jigsaw, because when he's faced with a problem, he goes to pieces.

Creation

Penfold was created by Brian Cosgrove and Mark Hall of Cosgrove/Hall Productions Ltd, and debuted in the cartoon Danger Mouse, episode 1 "Rogue Robots" on 28th September 1981. He was voiced by British comedian Terry Scott.

Character Development

Always eager, easily surprised, often dense and frequently terrified, Penfold was a faithful sidekick and accompanied Danger Mouse on all his missions, including those on the printed page. Between May 1982 and November 1985 he appeared in Look-In Magazine's Danger Mouse comic strip, which was written by Angus P. Allan and drawn by Arthur Ranson. He also appeared in the six Danger Mouse Annuals.
name: Penfold

deck: Charlie Gray is an employee at Stark Industries who was once possessed by Lucifer.
description:
Origin

Charlie Gray was a high school football star who ended up working as a guard in Stark Industries. Disgruntled at how his life has turned out, Charlie took up an offer from Lucifer to trap Tony Stark in exchange for power. However Charlie's wife Wilma managed to talk him to his senses and he soon gave up his quest for power.

Creation

Charlie Gray was created by writer Archie Goodwin and artist George Tuska. He first appeared in "Who Serves Lucifer?" in 1969.
name: Charlie Gray

deck: Wilma Gray is the wife of a Stark Industries employee who stopped her possessed husband from kidnapping Tony Stark.
description:
Origin

Wilma Gray's husband Charlie is a guard at Stark Industries. When her husband was possessed by Lucifer, she stoped him from kidnapping Tony Stark.

Creation

Wilma Gray was created by writer Archie Goodwin and artist George Tuska. She first appeared in "Who Serves Lucifer?" in 1969.
name: Wilma Gray

deck: Villainous toad whose plots to conquer the world are constantly thwarted by Danger Mouse.
description:
Origin

Baron Silas Greenback is the arch enemy of Danger Mouse, a villainous amphibian constantly plotting world conquest or worldwide destruction.

Creation

Baron Greenback was created by Brian Cosgrove and Mark Hall of Cosgrove/Hall Productions Ltd, and debuted in the cartoon Danger Mouse, episode 1 "Rogue Robots" on 28th September 1981. He was voiced by British actor Edward Kelsey.

Character Development

The hoarse-voiced toad Baron Greenback uses a never ending supply of advanced gadgets and weapons in his plots to conquer the world and / or destroy his hated foe Danger Mouse. His constant companion is his pet caterpillar Nero, and he is aided and abetted by his incompetent henchman Stiletto Mafiosa (a crow), and, less frequently, his even more incompetent henchman Leatherhead (another crow). He also teamed up with the then-villainous Count Duckula on one occasion.

Greenback appeared in 56 out of the 89 Danger Mouse cartoons. Between May 1982 and November 1985 he frequently appeared in Look-In Magazine's Danger Mouse comic strip, which was written by Angus P. Allan and drawn by Arthur Ranson. He also appeared in the six Danger Mouse Annuals.
name: Baron Greenback

deck: Nomi Blume is a mutant in the Ultimate Universe and a rival to Kitty Pryde for leadership of the remaining mutant population.
description:
Major Storylines

Reborn and His Will Be Done

Nomi Blume first appears as one of a large group of children rescued from Stryker by the X-men in New York. She subsequently lives in the Morlock Tunnels with them. When Kitty Pryde decides to lead the X-men into a war against the Sentinals which are attacking the mutant population, Nomi volunteers to join them. However, Kitty refuses, stating that Nomi is too young. At the same time, she reassures the girl that she is a born leader, and promises that, when Nomi is old enough, she can come and join Kitty in her fight. Kitty leaves Nomi, and the other children, in the care of Johnny Storm, who has been living with them in the Morlock Tunnels since the storyline began.

At The Speed of Mach Two

Nomi reapears in, and is the focus of, the Point One issue, 'At The Speed of Mach Two'. Initially, she appears to be there to help, and spots and removes a piece of shrapnel from Iceman's skull. However, it is quickly shown that she has become much more violent and powerful. She later attacks Kitty, demonstrating her magnetic abilities for the first time, levitating Kitty off of the ground while preventing her from phasing. She states her anger at Kitty for allowing other mutants to accept the mutant 'cure', blaming her for apparently abandoning the war for mutant liberation. She muses that she could kill Kitty, and threatens her with a piece of shrapnel. She is interrupted by Rogue, and leaves.

Reservation X

Nomi is one of the twenty mutants who refuse the mutant cure offered by Captain America's government. Together with Kitty and the X-men, she is transported to the new mutant reservation. There, she challenges Kitty's authority, demanding that the group elect a new leader. She cites the poor quality of the land on which they have been settled, and suggests that they demand better. Although she loses the vote, she manages to stir up a sizeable minority of the group against Kitty. Her followers include Blackheath, Warpath, Psylocke, and Shola Inkosi.

Once the group reach the settlement, which they name 'Utopia', Nomi's group breaks away, claiming a block of shelters to themselves. Although Blackheath continues to work with Kitty on a project to make the land more hospitable, he aligns himself with Nomi, acting as a spy for her in Kitty's group. Nomi also has Psylocke use her powers to telepathically spy on Kitty. In this way, Nomi learns that Kitty has been given a gun (the only weapon on the Reservation) by Nick Fury.

Codenames

To date, Nomi has been given two different codenames. The first, 'Mach Two', was given to her in 'His Will Be Done'. This same title was given to her after 'United We Stand', and is the codename by which she is addressed by other characters. However, during her brief appearances in 'Divided We Fall' and 'United We Stand', she is identified as 'Purge', although no character addresses or refers to her using this name in the narrative.

Powers and Abilities

Nomi's mutant powers give her control over magnetic fields. Initially, this power was only minor, and she herself states that the most she was able to do was magnetize her ankles, allowing her to hang upside down from the pipes in the tunnels to amuse the younger children.

However, when the character reappears in 'At The Speed of Mach Two', her powers have advanced considerably. She is now able to move any object providing it contains a sufficient amount of metal. To date, she has been shown levitating an entire trailer without any visible difficulty, and manipulating a piece of shrapnel to use as a weapon. Nomi is also able to levitate people, and can isolate and control the iron in another person's blood. When she does so to Kitty Pryde, she is able to use this aspect of her powers to stop her from phasing.

issue_credits.name: Natural Resources, Part Five; Utopia United!
Divided We Fall; Chapter One: Road Worn

name: Mach 2

volume_credits.name: Ultimate Comics: Divided We Fall, United We Stand
Ultimate Comics X-Men By Brian Wood

deck: An evil spirit who lives inside Saint Sinner.
description:
Origin

He has four brothers: Clocksmith, Unlockingsmith, Bladesmith and Soulsmith. Runesmith and his brothers were originally all part of one being. Thanks to Kento Canto, who accidentally divided the group into seperate entities, the demonic brothers were set loose to cause mayhem and destruction.
name: Runesmith

deck: An elderly man who found a fountain of youth below the streets of Chicago, and with it came the powers to use a Witchblade like force known as The Flesh.

deck: A young woman who saves Saint Sinner's life. She is later revealed to be an angel.
description:
Origin

Regina appears in Saint Sinner #1 as a good Samaritan who saves Saint Sinner's life. When he throws himself into the water, in an attempt to drown himself and be rid of Runesmith, she pulls him from the water and revives him. He then strangles her for her trouble, at the insistence of Runesmith, who urges him to "kill the harlot". What neither Saint Sinner nor Runesmith realize is that Regina is really an angel. When she dies, her soul enters his body, and the battle for control of Saint Sinner begins.

Creation

Regina was created by Clive Barker.

Character Evolution

Regina later reveals to Saint Sinner that she was summoned when Kento Canto split the Smiths into seperate beings, and that her job is to hunt down Runesmith.
name: Regina

deck: Given power by the Guardians of the Universe, the mysterious First Lantern was locked away and guarded by another group of the Guardian's species, after his powers were determined to be too great and dangerous. The Guardians used his powers to help create the Third Army.
description:
Pre-Crisis

Originally, the being called Volthoom existed on Earth-Three as a Tibetan monk. He had in his possession a unique power ring and lantern of great power unrelated to the Green Lantern Corps. Both the ring and the lantern were claimed by an individual who used them for his own ill-gotten gains, joining the Crime Syndicate of America as the nefarious villain Power Ring. It is unknown what became of the monk.

Post-Crisis

After Earth-Three was erased from existence during the Crisis on Infinite Earths and the Antimatter Universe was established as a complete mirror opposite of the regular DC Universe, Volthoom was once again established as a spirit trapped inside a power ring. The ring was a mixed blessing, however, as the wearer (Power Ring) gained great power but was bound to the ring and subject to Volthoom. The spirit constantly plagued Power Ring's mind in a subversive manner in an effort to ultimately gain control of him. It was theorized (but never stated in-comic) that Volthoom was the antimatter counterpart of Starheart. Power Ring was unable to remove the ring without having another accept the curse, and passed it on to a successor by trickery. Likewise, this pattern manifested when the new Earth-3 was created by the machinations of Mr. Mind.

Post-Flashpoint

Now, it seems these versions are just counterparts of a nigh-all powerful sociopath imprisoned by the Guardians of the Universe after once being their soldier.

Who and what Volthoom is, or was, is still a mystery. Eons ago, he was the very first Lantern created and empowered by the Guardians of the Universe in order to protect life. Rather than just wielding the green light of willpower, Volthoom seems to be able to wield a mixture of all seven parts of the Emotional Spectrum. However, this appeared to backfire, as Volthoom revealed himself to be, in the Guardians own words, an emotional sadist who enjoyed playing with the souls of living things for his own amusement.

Trying to rectify their mistake, the Guardians sealed Volthoom away, and half of their tribe chose to spend eternity keeping him imprisoned while the other half would go on to make other attempts at policing the universe. Some eons later, the Guardians returned to retrieve Volthoom from the brethren in a megalomaniacal attempt to eradicate free will in all living beings in order to protect life. They began siphoning off his energy in order to create the Third Army, mindless beings with no will of their own anymore, thinking that by eradicating emotion but not killing individuals the universe will finally be in complete order. But they failed and Volthoom escaped and took back all of the power the Guardians had stolen from him.

When he learned that his power had been corrupted by the Guardians lack of emotion, Volthoom set out on a quest to purify his reality-warping powers by consuming the emotions of beings who represented the various aspects of the Emotional Spectrum like Carol Ferris and Kyle Rayner.

Rebirth

Volthoom makes his debut in issue 9 of Green Lanterns. At the end of issue 9 he approaches a guy named Frank Laminski who is in despair and anger since he didn't get the green lantern ring. Volthoom tells him that he's been monitoring him for a while and tells him about the phantom ring. Frank is a sturdy person and tells Volthoom he'll do whatever needs to be done.

Later on Frank and Volthoom find Guardian Rami on earth, he possesses the phantom ring. While Volthoom handles Rami the hard way, Frank puts on the ring. Volthoom tells Rami that Rami ruined his life, that he is a traitor. Rami and the other Guardians put a battery in his life and now he looks like a ghost. He feels hatred with deep indignation.

Now Volthoom is in Rami's body while Rami's ghost is in a glowing ball in the hands of Volthoom. The other Lanterns/Guardians don't know Rami is actually not Rami, in fact he's Volthoom. They trust 'Rami' and he may stay on earth as protector.

deck: What if the Hulk was a teddy bear?
description:
Origin

Teddy Scare was a normal looking teddy bear that belonged to a young boy, Eddie. However, when provoked or when his owner was in trouble, Teddy could transform into a hulking, feral, animated bear. Though he generally protected Eddie, he wasn't averse to turning on him if Eddie angered him, such as the time Eddie accidentally sat on him.

Creation

Teddy Scare first appeared in Monster Fun, and was normally illustrated by artist Barrie Appleby.

Character Development

After debuting in later issues of Monster Fun, Teddy Scare was one of the characters who survived that comics' demise and merger with Buster. He continued to appear in his new home for just over a year.
name: Teddy Scare

deck: Charles is an assistant working for Looker.

deck: Don Massimo Cesare is a hundred year old godfather respected by all the families. He is killed by the Punisher on his hundred birthday.
description:
The Punisher: In the Beginning

A local Mafia family celebrates the 100th birthday of Don Massimo Cesare. Every crime family in the US sent a representative to the party to pay homage. The Punisher crashes the party and shoots the Don then slaughters everyone else.

Punisher War-Zone

Massimo Cesare is renamed Gaitano Cesare and played by John Dunn-Hill. Cesare was being prosecuted in a RICO trial. Cesare and his mob were responsible for 200 murders. The prosecutor's star witness was Eugene Gordlock whose testimony could put Cesare behind bars. Eugene feared for his life and asked the judge to be recused from the case. Eugene was later gunned down in his own front yard by Billy "The Beaut" Russoti. After 8 weeks, the case was thrown out of court due to a mistrial. This is not the first time Cesare has escaped justice.

Cesare celebrates his victory in court and has a meeting with his unstable nephew Billy Russoti. Russoti has arranged a transaction with Cristu Bulat. Bulat needs Russoti's customs handler Simmons to ensure that his union dock workers unload and protect his shipment when it arrives in NY. In exchange, Russoti will get 10 million for his assistance. Cesare doesn't like the idea when he hears that shipment is a "biological package".

Cesare fears Bulat will sell this package to a terrorist cell in Queens, NY. Russoti tries to ease his uncle's concerns by Bulat's guarantee that the package will be out of the city in no time at all. Cesare puts his foot down that he doesn't want his mob involved in this transaction. Cesare goes on by insulting his nephew and drudging up the fact that he had Billy's younger brother Jim institutionalized. Billy's right hand man calms the situation down and Cesare leaves the room to join everyone else at the banquet table.

Cesare sits down with other members of his family and those who remain loyal to him. Punisher temporarily cuts the power to the house and executes everyone at the banquet table. Punisher decapitates Cesare. Cesare's wife goes for his gun but the Punisher disarms her and snaps her neck.
name: Massimo Cesare

Alan Ford
Space Ace
deck: Spanish space hero.
description:
Origin

After discovering a dying alien from Altair, a Rockie mountain forest ranger is gifted the alien's spaceship and memory-transferring helmet and becomes Johnny Galaxia, working for Earth's fledgling Space Patrol.

Creation

Johnny Galaxia was created by Spanish artist Josep Beá and Blay Navarro for Selecciones Illustradas in 1959. Selecciones Illustradas then sold the series to various countries over the next few years. In Australia he became Johnny Galaxy, while in Britain he was sold both to Atlas Publishing, who adapted his stories to become new adventures of their existing character Space Ace (in later issues of Lone Star and from the 14th issue of Space Ace on), and L. Miller and Son, who used him under his original name of Johnny Galaxia as back up features in both Marvelman and Young Marvelman; for a period of time both British companies were using the character simultaneously under these different names. In Italy, where an existing character was already called Gionni Galassia (Johnny Galaxy), the Spanish creation was renamed Alan Ford. In France he became Johnny Galaxie, appearing in Super Boy and Tenax.
name: Johnny Galaxia

volume_credits.name: Space Ace, Guardian of the Universe

aliases:
Guardian of the Universe
Ace Hart
deck: Atlas Publishing's space hero.
description:
Origin

After being struck by a meteorite, Texan sheriff Ace Hart becomes immune to radiation, and joins the Space Squadron, soon earning the rank of commander and the nickname Space Ace, captaining the spaceship LS1.

Creation

Ace Hart debuted in the first issue of Lone Star, a comic published by Die Cast Metal Toys as a tie-in to their toys. Foldes Press, who already published titles involving the space hero Ace Hart the Atom Man, unsurprisingly objected to DCMT's Ace Hart, and so with the third issue of Lone Star the character took the name Space Ace.

Character Development

Space Ace continued to be published through the entire run of Lone Star, with Ron Turner becoming the regular artist. Atlas Publishing later bought Lone Star, and, while keeping Space Ace there, also promoted him to his own title, Space Ace, Guardian of the Universe. The character also starred in several of Atlas' annual Book of Space Adventures. After Ron Turner left the series, Atlas purchased the rights to reprint the Spanish series Johnny Galaxia, and adapted that different character's adventures to appear to be the continuing adventures of Space Ace.

Major Story Arcs

In the near future, when man has conquered the stars, Ace Hart was the sheriff of Tarrant County, Texas, until he was struck by a meteorite. Gaining an immunity to radiation from this strange encounter, he enlisted in the United Planets' Space Squadron, and was assigned command of the new spaceshop LS1, exploring space and investigating interstellar crimes. His most trusted ally was Sergeant Bill Crag, but other crew members included the pilot Bill Haines, and scientists Professor McKay and Dr. Wang Fu.
name: Space Ace

volume_credits.name: Space Ace, Guardian of the Universe

deck: A priest hero produced by Fujimi Shobo manga/comic books.
description:
Origin

A high ranking Monster or Mazokou serving as both a priest and general. Zellos as travelled with and gone against Lina Inverse depending on what his masters order him to do. He usually takes a human form and acts like a trickster priest.

Current Events

Xellos appears in the manga/anime.

Powers & Abilities

Xellos is a priest/general, and presumably is an adept magician. He can teleport, emit powerful blasts, project a protective field, or even move at incredible speeds. He is also an above average hand to hand combatant, and is very intelligent.
name: Xellos

In her second appearance, she is young again, having gained what she sought by other means.
